citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats.
citations.narrative:
On March 15, 2024 69 dogs arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) from Ben Gurion
International Airport (Lod, Israel) on Flight ICL503 (AWB# 70050760764).
The primary enclosures for 4 dogs were damaged during transit. The kennels containing the following animals were in
various states damage at arrival: “Bueno” microchip# 939000011010902, “Sabah Kid 3” microchip #900215001962234,
“Huwara” microchip #900233000326542, and “Malika” microchip #900233000326545. All dogs were safety moved to
compliant transport enclosures prior to further transit.
A female mixed breed, brown and white, dog (“Sabah Kid 3” microchip #900215001962234) escaped her primary
enclosure during transit after damaging the rear of her kennel. Members of the organization traveling with the dogs were
able to secure “Sabah Kid 3” for the remainder of the flight.
Primary enclosures must be strong enough to securely contain animals and to withstand the normal rigors of
transportation.
This inspection was conducted at associated cargo areas with facility and airline representatives. The exit interview was
conducted by phone with an airline representative.
n

narrative:
3.15(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live dogs and cats. 
On March 15, 2024 69 dogs arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) from Ben Gurion 
International Airport (Lod, Israel) on Flight ICL503 (AWB# 70050760764). 
 
The primary enclosures for 4 dogs were damaged during transit. The kennels containing the following animals were in 
various states damage at arrival: “Bueno” microchip# 939000011010902, “Sabah Kid 3” microchip #900215001962234, 
“Huwara” microchip #900233000326542, and “Malika” microchip #900233000326545. All dogs were safety moved to 
compliant transport enclosures prior to further transit.  
 
A female mixed breed, brown and white, dog (“Sabah Kid 3” microchip #900215001962234) escaped her primary 
enclosure during transit after damaging the rear of her kennel. Members of the organization traveling with the dogs were 
able to secure “Sabah Kid 3” for the remainder of the flight. 
 
Primary enclosures must be strong enough to securely contain animals and to withstand the normal rigors of 
transportation. 
 
This inspection was conducted at associated cargo areas with facility and airline representatives. The exit interview was 
conducted by phone with an airline representative. 
 
 n
